newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine gov't says Peronists support labor laws.
newsitem.headline: Argentine gov't says Peronists support labor laws.

text.p: Argentina's governing Peronist Party supports planned measures to cut labor costs, Cabinet Chief Jorge Rodriguez said Wednesday.
Rodriguez's comments to local radio came despite the failure of the Peronists' national council to give outright support to the measures in a meeting late Tuesday.
After a three-hour debate, the council unanimously approved a general statement saying only that it backed government measures against unemployment.
But Rodriguez welcomed the document as a gesture of support for the government and said that he expected Peronist congressmen to pass the measures.
"We understand that this measure will have the support of the congressional wing, which does not mean it will not be debated," he said.

Tuesday's document expressed the Peronists' determination to "struggle tirelessly for the economic model to be complemented by the measures proposed by its political leaders to wage a firm war against unemployment."
Leaders of the CGT union confederation, which is linked to the Peronists, attended the meeting, and the declaration made no criticism of Thursday's planned 36-hour strike.
Former CGT chief Gerardo Martinez said the document showed "there was no support for the labor flexibilization plan."
Labor Minister Armando Caro Figueroa said the government might pass the measures by decree if Congress does not pass the measures this year.
The strike is being led by the CGT in protest at both 17.1 percent unemployment and President Carlos Menem's drive for fiscal austerity and more flexible labor laws.

The package of labor laws includes measures to reduce restrictions on working hours and holidays, allow for salaries to be partly linked to profits, make overtime payable in rest-time, and create a private workers' compensation fund.
